Same code on js es6+:   class Robot {     constructor(name, color, weight) {         this.name = name         this.color = color         this.weight = weight         this.lookingAt     }      printName() {         console.log(`My name is ${this.name}`)     } }  r1 = new Robot('Jimmy', 'Purple', 30) r2 = new Robot('Jotaro', 'Black', 100)  console.log(r1.lookingAt = r2, r2.lookingAt = r1)  class Person {     constructor(name, personallity, sitting) {         this.name = name         this.personallity = personallity         this.sitting = sitting         this.robotOwned     }      isSitting() {         this.sitting = true     }      standUp() {         this.sitting = false     } }  p1 = new Person('Alice', 'Aggressive', false) p2 = new Person('Hendrix', 'Talkative', true)  p1.robotOwned = r2 p2.robotOwned = r1 p1.robotOwned.printName() p2.robotOwned.printName()   /////////////////////////////////////////////   One thing i didnt expect is the result of calling print on r1 and r2 looking at each other:   <ref *1> Robot {   name: 'Jotaro',   color: 'Black',   weight: 100,   lookingAt: Robot {     name: 'Jimmy',     color: 'Purple',     weight: 30,     lookingAt: [Circular *1]   }   name: 'Jimmy',   color: 'Purple',   weight: 30,   lookingAt: Robot {     name: 'Jotaro',     color: 'Black',     weight: 100,     lookingAt: [Circular *1]   } }   Running this on node.js.

Rohit Vijayvargiya Robot is not a data type... an object is declared upon a blueprint which is normally a class. Robot is a class that generalises all robots and can be used to make Robot objects. The programmer makes these classes and so can call them anything (Apple, Banana, Monkey, etc). In order to make a robot object (in this case r1), u will have to declare it as follows: Robot r1 = new Robot(); this will create a Robot (r1) which will have the properties specified in the class Robot. So Robot is not a data type, it’s just a class that is being used to declare Robot objects.

Try this in C# ---Person.cs--- public class Person     {         string name;         string personality;         bool isSitting;         public Robot robotOwned;         //robot object.         public Person(string name, string persona, bool isSitting)         {             this.name = name;             personality = persona;             this.isSitting = isSitting;         }         public string getName()         {             return "Human " + this.name+" ";         }         public void SitDown()         {             this.isSitting = true;         }         public void StandUp()         {             this.isSitting = false;         }         public string PersonDetails()         {             return this.name + " is " + this.personality + ". " + "Is Sitting: " +                 this.isSitting.ToString() + "\n";         }     }  ---Robot.cs--- public class Robot     {         string name;         string color;         int weight;         public Robot(string n, string c, int w)         {             this.name = n;             this.color = c;             this.weight = w;         }         public void IntroduceSelf()         {             Console.WriteLine("I am a robot. My Name is: " + this.name);         }         public string getName()         {             return "Robot " + this.name + " ";         }     }  ---PersonAndRobot.cs--- class PersonAndRobot     {                  public static void Main(string[] args)         {             Robot r1 = new Robot("Tom", "Red", 30);             Robot r2 = new Robot("Jerry", "Blue", 40);             r1.IntroduceSelf();             r2.IntroduceSelf();             Person[] persons = new Person[2];             persons[0] = new Person("Alice", "Agressive", false);             persons[1] = new Person("Becky", "Talkative", true);              persons[0].SitDown();             persons[0].robotOwned = r1;             persons[1].SitDown();             persons[1].robotOwned = r2;             foreach(Person person in persons)             {                 Console.WriteLine(person.getName() + " owns " + person.robotOwned.getName());                //or simply:                  person.robotOwned.IntroduceSelf();             }             Console.ReadKey();          }     }

As the other guy mentioned, Python, C, and Java are all good to learn. Python is the least picky in terms of syntax and I found to be the one I picked up the fastest. Python also has a lot of built in "methods" which are functions that the language has built-in. You could watch a video explaining it. I think you should start with python using the pycharm IDE.

everyone keeps saying that python has an easy syntax, and good fot beginner, but coming from Java and C# there are a few things that are problematic I think. for example in Java or C# you declare and initialize a variable with it's Datatype. like ''int robotAge = 25''  I think that this approach has several advantages over pythons simple ''robotAge = 25'' approach.  1: if I see code from a different Person, I know that this variable is being initialized right know and not already earlier and got changed now. In Python I often wonder if a variable in initialized or just reassigned right know.  2: the Compiler knows that it isn't possible to put a String inside my int variable and prints an error notice. In Python it doesn't because values are not really stored in variables but the variables point to the value that is stored somewhere else. so something like this is possible too: zahl = 3 print(zahl)    // prints 3 zahl = 'hello' print(zahl)   // prints hello  I think that this is a Problem if I have a method avaiting a string or even another method and it gets an integer or something. catching exceptions is all good and stuff, but with this kind of workflow I would have to put every line of code in Try and catch blocks.   that are reasons why I would start with either Java or C#
